abstract.text: An abstract base class for subscriptions.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: A subscription acts like a persistent query on the server that can track the creation, deletion, and modification of records. When changes occur, they trigger the delivery of push notifications so that your app can respond appropriately.
Subscriptions don’t become active until you save them to the server and the server has time to index them. To save a subscription, use an instance of
or the
method of
. To cancel a subscription, delete the corresponding subscription from the server.
You don’t need to enable push notifications for the app’s explicit App ID in your developer account at
to receive subscription notifications. Xcode automatically adds the APNs entitlement to your entitlement file when you enable CloudKit. To learn about enabling CloudKit, see
Most of a subscription’s configuration happens at initialization time. You must, however, specify how to deliver push notifications to the user’s device. Use the
property to configure the delivery options. You must save the subscription before the changes take effect.
Create subscriptions in the development environment first and then promote them to production.  Attempting to create a subscription directly in the production environment results in an error.

When CloudKit modifies a record and triggers a subscription, the server sends push notifications to all devices with that subscription except for the one that makes the original changes. For subscription-based push notifications, the server can add data to the notification payload that indicates the condition that triggers the notification. In the
method of your app delegate, create a
object from the provided
dictionary. You can then query it for the information that’s relevant to the notification.
In addition to sending a record ID with a push notification, you can ask the server to send a limited amount of data from the record that triggers the notification. Use the
property of the object you assign to
to specify the keys to include.

APNs limits the size of a push notification’s payload and CloudKit may omit keys and other pieces of data to keep the payload’s size under that limit. If this happens, you can fetch the entire payload from the server using an instance of
. This operation provides instances of
or
, which contain information about the push notifications that CloudKit delivers to your app.

abstract.text: Store structured app and user data in iCloud containers that all users of your app can share.
An object that represents a collection of record zones and subscriptions.
Saves a specific subscription.
The abstract base class for operations that act upon databases in CloudKit.
A subscription that generates push notifications when CloudKit modifies records in a database.
An operation for modifying one or more subscriptions.
The abstract base class for CloudKit notifications.
A notification that triggers when a record that matches the subscription’s predicate changes.
A subscription that generates push notifications when CloudKit modifies records that match a predicate.
A notification that triggers when the contents of a record zone change.
A subscription that generates push notifications when CloudKit modifies records in a specific record zone.
An abstract base class for subscriptions.
A type that represents a subscription’s identifier.
An object that describes the configuration of a subscription’s push notifications.
The names of fields to include in the push notification’s payload.
Constants that identify a subscription’s behavior.
The configuration for a subscription’s push notifications.
The subscription’s unique identifier.
The subscription’s unique identifier.
The behavior that a subscription provides.
A type that represents a subscription’s identifier.
Tells the app that a remote notification arrived that indicates there is data to be fetched.
The root class of most Objective-C class hierarchies, from which subclasses inherit a basic interface to the runtime system and the ability to behave as Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A protocol that enables encoding and decoding in a manner that is robust against object substitution attacks.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
